article.title: Network Analysis of Gene Transcriptions of Arabidopsis thaliana in Spaceflight Microgravity
article.abstract: The transcriptomic datasets of the plant model organism Arabidopsis thaliana grown in the International Space Station provided by GeneLab have been mined to isolate the impact of spaceflight microgravity on gene expressions related to root growth.

sections.introduction: Gravity plays a key role in plant growth [1]. Arabidopsis thaliana (Arabidopsis) is a flowering plant that has been chosen by biologists as a model plant organism to study the effects of gravity and other environmental stressors, since it has a short life cycle and because of the existence of a multitude of mutants and transgenic plants.
sections.methods: We have mined GeneLab GLDS-7 and GLDS -120 datasets for identifying hub genes that are affected by spaceflight.
sections.results: The Pearson correlation method is used to generate weighted directed graphs.
sections.discussion: Graph-based network analysis methods and results have been presented for transcriptomic regulatory GeneLab Arabidopsis datasets.

technologies: least absolute shrinkage and selection operator

technologies_detail.text: least absolute shrinkage and selection operator
technologies_detail.normalized: least absolute shrinkage and selection operator

article.insights_summary: This study used network analysis to identify genes that are differentially expressed in Arabidopsis thaliana grown in spaceflight microgravity compared to on the ground. The results show that spaceflight microgravity affects the expression of genes involved in root growth and cell wall biosynthesis.
article.acknowledgments: The material contained in this document is based upon work supported by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) grant 80NSSC19M0167.
